title-group.article-title: Captive on the Literacy Frontier: Mary Rowlandson, James Smith, and Charles Johnston

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2003 The University of North Carolina Press

ref.mixed-citation: James Merrell also breaks down a study into "several different contact areas—lin- guistic, economic, diplomatic, legal and religious—where Indian met colonist" (125).
Chafe and Tannen offer a helpful brief overview of the thesis and its "corrective" critiques (391-95).

Hambrick-Stowe, who states that Rowlandson's narrative "was a devotional exercise in the tradition of the journal and the spiritual autobiogra- phy, related to the discipline of meditative self-examination" (259).

Ebersole's principal target is Mitchell Breitweiser, who suggests that even if Mather did not directly impose himself on the narrative, Rowlandson realized that conforming to his stylesheet was the only way "her thoughts and words could escape the eventual oblivion of isolated memory" (8).
Christopher Castiglia also—paren- thetically—alludes to the possibility that the typological language in Rowland- son's narrative might stem from a "ministerial hand" (50).
Henwood, Logan, and Toulouse ("Strategies")
Neal Salisbury's The Sov- ereignty and Goodness of God by Mary Rowlandson with Related Documents

Ong, the transition from the spoken to the written word is a shift from the ephemeral domain of sound to the perdurable realm of sight; in "oral-aural" cultures, the spoken word, which "exists only as it is going out of existence," is powerful because it signifies the immanent presence of a speaker (31).
Ruth Finnegan points out that anthopological fieldwork is carried out in a colonial setting where the subjects are at least aware of literacy; primary orality is extinct (139-40).
Wyss's illuminating reading of the redemption correspondence and other documents related to Rowlandson's narrative (39-50).

Breitwieser remarks on Rowlandson's mention of a distant event: "Such connec- tions between personal and group experience, even at the sparse level of 'at the same time as,' are almost entirely absent from the narrative" (5).

Wyss, observing that the note on the Medfield battlefield has been attributed to James Printer, reads the devaluation of Indian "lives" differently: as reflective of the self-abnegation urged by Puritan missionaries: "[I]f Native lives are insignifi- cant, then Philip's losses in the war truly are meaningless, while the presumably superior English must sustain enormous loss. The language of abjection thus be- comes a revolutionary weapon that James Printer can wield against the English" (43-44).
"A Pris- oner of War Adopted by the Iroquois" 260
Mer- rell, 126-31.
Smith of the 1782 massacre of the Gnaddenhutten mission: "This was an act of barbarity beyond any thing I ever knew to be com- mitted by the savages themselves" (346).

Smith's logic, however, is consistent, because Smith considers the "scattered or- der" of Indian warfare, which to ignorant observers seemed chaotic and barbaric, to be more sophisticated, requiring greater coordination and discipline, than the foolhardy "close order" of European battle formations (346).
White 187.

Gustafson, with reference to the title of a recent book by Philip Deloria: "Viewed in relation to native American diplomatic eloquence ... the oratorical public culture of the Revolution can be seen as a form of 'Playing Indian,' as well as playing Greek or Roman" (xix).
Johnston's narrative in his Voyage dans Les Etats Unis d'Amerique
Sayre's discussion of beaver lore on the frontier (Sauvages 218-47).
Sayre (Sauvages 79-123).
Sau- vages 122

Salisbury and others have noted the "suggestions in her narrative and elsewhere that Rowlandson also wrote in order to clear her name with respect to a num- ber of rumors and innuendos," including the suggestion of a forced marriage (43).

Nye writes that upon Smith's return to Pennsylvania his friends and family found that he had changed significantly: "At first they scarcely knew him because of his changed appearance and manner of speech—deliberate and sonorous, like that of the Indians—accompanied by graceful gestures, also an Indian charac- teristic. In his moccasins he walked like an Indian, with his toes pointed straight forward or slightly turned in, like a bear. He became known locally as 'Indian Jimmie'" (7).
Hallowell 523
Hall, "Introduction," 13-25.
Le- pore's Name of War
James Axtell's brief essay "The Power of Print in the Eastern Woodlands"
Axtell 87-99
Lepore (Name 27).
Sturtevant; and Lepore, (A is for American, 73-90).
